+montanus777
Well I meant that Russians seem to be fine with the Mojave. I understand

comments.author: Max Siemens

comments.text:
+Max Siemens
yes, there is sun during the winter. the days are just shorter and the 
temperature is colder. and i think the climate of DC is also much more 
fitting to russia than the climate of the other parts. (same with the UK or 
france ... and maybe even japan.)
and with locations i don't only mean monuments, but also the look of a 
city. i think many non-americans would recognize new york or san francisco 
too (even without monuments). but i think for example that many 
non-americans (that didn't visit the states) couldn't tell the difference 
between LA and miami (it's just some american city with a beach) or the 
difference between detroit and atlanta (it's just some american city 
without beach).
comments.author: montanus777

comments.text:
+montanus777
Damn don't you guys get barely any sunlight in the winter? Of course you 
could relate to the gloomyness of Fallout 3. The first Fallouts were in 
environments much more like FNV and I would say that a very good majority 
of the Bethesda fan base is American including the non-American Russian 
community that seems fine with it. Also, how many internationally 
recognized monuments are there in America?
comments.author: Max Siemens

comments.text:
i hope fallout 4 plays in a location of moderate climate, that even 
non-americans (that never visited the states) recognize, when they see it. 
this is why i (as a german) liked the atmosphere of fallout 3 the most.
first the climate around washington is comparable to germany. for germany 
has no desert i felt like 'no wonder, the villages in the mojave are empty, 
cause it's the f***ing desert' and it didn't really feel post apocalyptic 
to me - but more like harsh nature.
second as a non-american you may know that there are places like reno, 
pittsburg, maryland etc. but you probably don't know what they look like 
nowadays. but when you see the capitol, the pentagon or the lincoln 
memorial you know where you are. and this makes you feel the catastrophic 
impact of the nuclear war, because it feels more real (not like a kind of a 
fantasy world).
so i hope bethesda also keeps the non-american gamers in mind. :)
comments.author: montanus777

comments.text:
for the main game has a point of no return during the main quest (and a 
boring ending), i think broken steel is the most important dlc. although 
maybe some of the other dlcs had better quests. also broken steel has some 
nice perks too and the rise of the level cap is awesome. only broken steel 
makes fallout 3 a real open world game without having to fear solving 
quests and suddenly ending the game. i also liked, that your actions really 
have an impact on the wasteland with broken steel, while most of the other 
quests during the main game don't really change that much for you.
(but i totally hated the albino scorpions being stronger than deathclaws. 
-.-)

Though rarely mentioned for a long period (since Fallout: Tactics) I feel 
the best faction to rebuild humanity is the Mid-West Brotherhood of Steel. 
They control(led) land from Chicago to NORAD and they also partially 
controlled St. Louis. They are slightly mentioned in New Vegas By the 
Legion. But I feel that they had Lyons' ideals before Lyons and it would be 
best if the Mid-West and the East could Unite or at least contact each 
other. In Fallout 3 the BOS said they had perviously tried to contact the 
Mid-West to no avail.﻿

comments.text:
Lyons ideals? They are heavily racists and mad for control. They provide 
protection (mainly against themselves, just like the mob) in exchange for 
money, resources and recruits and they let non-humans into their ranks only 
because they see them as a tool to an end. Most importantly, they only do 
that because they are isolated from the other chapters, unable to request 
reinforcement, armors, weapons and ammunitions or even establish 
communication with the core chapter. If they dont do that, they are 
doomed... At the end of the game, if you let them have the control, their 
first order is to exterminate all non-humans and all opposition.

+carcotasu081 I know it's a different time line from ours but would the 
Soviet Union still have taken over East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Poland 
etc? I suppose it would make more sense or at least add more incentive for

have happened, at least not the same way anyway since they seem to be more

comments.text: Oh that makes sense. Thanks for your words of wisdom. +jordan wootton
comments.author: EXTREMEKIWI115

comments.text:
That is because it is still putting out active radiation and fallout. They 
have not yet fixed the problem. They are still pouring in seawater and 
dumping pollution into the water.

Also my bad here. I forgot to mention that the worst of the fallout is 
gone. There are still trace amounts that take years and years to go away 
but they are relatively harmless. Most of the radiation and almost all of 
the harmful radiation from the great war would be gone in a few years. 
Thats why in fallout new vegas the lake is not polluted. If it rained 
radiation how long do you think that water would stay clean? Same with 
fallout 3. Only the ground water is radioactive because its touching the 
radioactive ground.
comments.author: jordan wootton

comments.text:
+jordan wootton That's strange, they're still saying that fallout is in the 
atmosphere from all the explosions in Japan.
comments.author: EXTREMEKIWI115

comments.text:
+EXTREMEKIWI115 Actually most of the rain would not be radioactive. Most 
clean water in the world would come from rain. The radioactive rain happens 
for about 2-5 weeks after nuclear strikes so I would assume that at maximum 
the nuclear rain would have lasted maybe a few years or so after the great 
war before everything settled down. Now the rain would be water that 
evaporated so it would be clean.

comments.text:
Chernobyl may not have ever happened in the fallout universe. The disaster 
happened in 1986 but the divergence happened between the end of the second 
world war and the 1960s. That means that Chernobyl may not have happened at 
all. And if it did it may not have happened in the way that it did our 
world. We will probably never know.

comments.text:
+montanus777 The Midwest Brotherhood of Steel has schematics of how to 
build their power armor and so have the ability to make more.  They also 
have taken control of several towns and tribal villages that they have 
begun to recruit new soldiers from their population.  This was before the 
NCR was founded this was when the NCR's first president was still a young 
woman.  The Midwest Brotherhood would have 2162-2281 to build up both 
resources troops and territory up and with superior training to the NCR 
they may have the capability to leave both the Bear and the Bull 
disemboweled. 
This is not based off the Fallout Tactics game this is based off the 
information presented by Bethesda as what is cannon.

comments.text:
If it is anything like creating a map using the crytek engine, I assume it 
would take weeks to get it perfectly flushed out. But, as this could be 
easily solved (just adding a length of mesh in the form of a tube, and 
having its texture be that of a rifling pattern similar to that of the one 
seen already, then spending an hour or so fine tuning it and rewatching it 
in its final form) I feel like its an appropriate thing to bring up.
And considering most people in the USA HAVE fired a gun before (About 
little under 70%) it is a relevant topic to induce.
comments.author: BoomBoomChicky

comments.text:
+BoomBoomChicky do you realise how long it takes to make an intro? i doubt 
the maker really gave a shit since the mass majority of the viewers havent 
even fired a weapon
comments.author: RictorScale

comments.text:
Look at the bullet at 0:03
Now look at these, as of yet unfired bullets. ( 
http://www.evergladesammo.com/pd-45-230gr-fmj-bullets.html )
You will see that after the conical part of the bullet, they are straight 
sided- this is the part that directly interacts with the side of the 
casing, and this length allows it to stay in place incase of bumps or what 
have you. It is also the surface that is being acted upon by the rifling 
inside the barrel, so the idea is that the more area covered by this 
rifling, the better the effects the rifling will have upon the bullet.

I am not saying that the .45 acp is 'Bigger" but instead "Longer" as I 
originally stated.
comments.author: BoomBoomChicky

comments.text:
+BoomBoomChicky XD daaaayyyyyyum,XD so you say the .45 bullets a bit 
bigger? so,what would you say the bullet presented is?
comments.author: cobraglatiator

comments.author: Butheadbros2

comments.text:
+Butheadbros2 I edit and film this series.
Originally the narrator was supposed to get into a VR pod in person and go 
to a pre war Pittsburgh ingame for the scene starting at 1:40.  However, 
there were no decent mods or vanilla areas available to reflect what 
Pittsburgh would of looked like, so it had to be cut. I had to use some old 
stock footage instead. I realize the gag intro doesn't match the video and 
it kinda nags at me too. Also, these episodes are produced around the 
script im given and I get the subsequent script after the previous video is 
completed, so It definitely wasn't the wrong intro.
comments.author: blaaah45

same location, and I did figure out that the inhabitants are not the same.

really people. Both the ghost people and trogs are both mutated humans as a 
result of the air in that area.
Haven looks a lot like the Sierra Madre (the actual casino, not the villa 
and such).
The ambience is very similar. Reddish skies.

Dead Money just reminded me a lot of The Pitt, is all I'm saying.

top_comment.text:
Regarding Fallout 4, we pretty much know where it's going to take place, 
not for sure, but we all know what it's probably going to be.  Don't get me 
wrong, the Commonwealth would be a great place for the game, but I have 
another interesting idea.  The city of Detroit is a hell hole now, but in 
the 1950s it was an American powerhouse.  With the split timeline, Detroit 
could possibly be the most advanced city in the Fallout universe.  Combine 
that with it's classic Motown culture, and we've got a hell of a ride 
gentlemen.﻿

top_comment.text:
Question of the Week: Throughout the Fallout series we see figures and 
organizations claiming they want to "rebuild" humanity. Which person or 
organization do you think stands the best chance of realizing their vision? 
Should we even want civilization to return to a world that was already been 
destroyed by her?

top_comment.text:
The Pitt sounds promising, indeed. Imagine! We can restore our vertibird 
fleet withing months rather than years! We'll also be able to reverse 
engineer and build one of our own Liberty Primes with those resources! And 
if everything goes as planned, we'll have another Mobile Platform Base 
operational withnin two years! Maybe three. We'll begin a clensing 
operation to secure the Pitt. Once it's secured, we'll resume our 
restoration effort. Truly, these are glorious times for the Enclave.﻿
top_comment.author: Augustus Autumn

comments.text:

captions.text:
Meet Joe. Joe is a new recruit in the United
States Army, and like any dutiful American,

he wishes to serve his country by shooting
up the bad guys. Do we throw Joe on the front

lines and hope he figures it out himself?
Nonsense! That would be a waste of a perfectly

good suit of Power Armor. Through the use
of tax payer money, and with aid from what

the egg heads are calling “Virtual Reality”,
Joe can break the chains of his physical form,

and experience war from the comfort of a cozy
pod. Into the pod steps a starry-eyed American,

and out comes a killing machine. A defender
of Liberty. A guardian of democracy. Now Joe’s

a true American hero, and you can be too.
Enlist in the United States Army, and experience
Virtual Reality- TODAY.
ED-NA, Begin Recording

The Mojave has to worry about slavers from
the Legion capturing folk. But at least when

you're grabbed by the Legion, you know where
you're heading. Out East in the Capital Wasteland

there are plenty of slavers, but it seems
like there aren't many slaves around. People

always wonder what happens to the unfortunates
who get nabbed, but it turns out that the

slavers in Paradise Falls are in the Export
business. When they capture someone, they

usually aren't sold locally, they get shipped
North to a place aptly named The Pitt.

Before the war, the Pitt was called Pittsburg,
in the Eastern Commonwealth. The Pittsburg

Chamber of Commerce produced some interactive
holotapes to draw in tourists, and show off

its thriving steel industry.
This is what it looked like in the late twenty

first century. There aren't many records of
what the city was like in the years following

the Great War. No reliable sources entered
the Pitt until about thirty years ago when

a Brotherhood of Steel chapter led by Paladin
Lyons passed through on their mission to explore

the East Coast.
When they arrived, it looked more like this.

While the West Coast was slowly marching back
towards civilization, Pittsburg had spent

a hundred and eighty years degenerating into
a genetic swamp with barely-human mutants
cannibalizing each other.

Different parts of the wasteland get their
own local flavor. In The Pitt, the unique

combination of radioactive runoff, and industrial
waste brought about what they call Troglodyte
Degeneration Condition.

Anyone who stays in the Pitt will start to
develop it after a few weeks. Most people

just get a case of ghouly-lookin' skin, but
many lose their higher cognitive abilities

eventually. The most unfortunate folk devolve
one step further and lose their humanity altogether.

These “Trogs” as they call them, crawl
around naked on all fours, and shun humanity
in favor of the shadows.

When the Brotherhood of Steel traveled through
The Pitt in 2255, Elder Lyons couldn't stand

seeing humanity reduced to such a state, so
he and his followers annihilated most of the
cannibals, the raiders, and mutants.
The Brotherhood called it “The Scourge”.

They brought fire and brimstone to hell, sacked
the city, and took what unmutated children

they found with them to Washington DC. A few
of those Pitt kids are now full members of

the Brotherhood's Capital Chapter. The Brotherhood
also left someone behind in the Pitt. A paladin

who had been wounded and trapped during the
Scourge. Ishmael Ashur.

Paladin Ashur was a loyal brother at one point,
but when awoke surrounded by raiders in the

ruins of the Pitt, he saw a city that held
promise. Pittsburg had once been called The

City of Steel, and Ashur knew that the secrets
of steel would let the wasteland rebuild America's
railways.

Noble goals, indeed, but the business of forging
iron ore into girders of steel is hard work.

Hard even during the height of civilization,
and even worse now. Given that people who

spend more than a few weeks in the Pitt end
up turning into troglodytes, it's not surprising

that there weren't many volunteers. The dwindling
population of the Pitt had to be inflated

with slaves, so Ashur has been importing his
labor force from the Capital Wasteland.

Slaves need a motivation, a reason to not
just lie down and let the Trogs tear their

throats out. For the slaves in The Pitt, their
hope is The Hole. A combat arena where the

brave can try to prove themselves worthy of
freedom by brawling in a crater filled with

radioactive sludge. Survive three rounds against
the most bloodthirsty people in The Pitt,

and you're free to go with an offer of joining
Ashur's army.

The gentleman's art of boxing has no place
in The Hole. Slaves fight with anything can

get their hands on, from mining equipment
to laser scatterguns, one person even won

their freedom using a board with a nail in
it.

Very few people actually make it out of The
Pitt, though. One person fought their way

free through The Hole and showed up in the
Capital Wasteland a few years ago carrying

holotapes that were supposedly recorded by
Paladin Ashur himself. If it's really him,

it seems that he had been trying to find a
cure for the Trog condition. Yet more “noble”
aspirations from a slave-owner.

Folk who want to see how things turned out
can take a handtruck there from Northern Maryland.

The rails go all the way up to The Pitt. No
matter your opinion on slave owning, that's

quite a feat of engineering, and a testament
to the potential of Ashur's vision of a reborn

world.
There's a chance that future generations will

actually restore the railways that once connected
both coasts of this continent. Getting across

the oceans is another story. A few folk with
funny accents claim that they're from overseas,

but ships that can navigate the water spouts
and sea critters are nearly impossible to find.
There's a fella who says his old paddleboat

could travel up and down the Atlantic Coast,
but the farthest anyone has ever gone and

returned is a swamp a little ways to the south.
It's a place of mysteries, and ancient magics,

or at least that's what you'll hear from the
few tourists who've been there and back. But
that- is a story for another day…
